messageBody:
> > Thanks for the example in design issues... but that isn't what I was
after.
> > I should have been more clear, and I will be next time.

> Ok. Point well taken. back to the main track.


> > I wanted to point out the potential flaws of design and
> > testing that could otherwise be missed when you put tests in the
same
> > package as production code. The production code should be tested in
the
> > same fashion it would be used by a client. A test is a client in
some
> > degree. In most cases clients exist outside of the package.
> > [..snip]
> > Thus,
> > I conclude, that testing the public interfaces of ALL objects (the
key being
> > ALL) should prove sufficient, thus not needing the tests to reside
in the
> > same package as their associated production code objects. Of
course, there
> > are exceptions... we have ways around those.

> In an ideal world, you're right. Testing *all* the public methods
should give you complete functional
> coverage.
> However:
> 1. You might want to put more stress on some classes and less on
others. In this case, you might want to
> test more then the public methods of critical-path components, and
less of the peripherals.

So design the objects that way. It will take a little more thought, a lot
more refactoring, but generally only one test-case :)

> 2. You might want to access non-public methods in your setUp /
tearDown.

Again, why? No one has yet given me one concrete answer as to why this
should be. It's all been ambiguous speculation.

> 3. Sometimes the tested class needs a sophisticated context in runtime
(EJB / Servlet). In this case, you
> might want to short circuit it in testing by calling protected /
default access methods that would be
> called by the public interface in production mode.

This short circuiting could be avoided by mature mock objects and a good
testing framework for these contexts.

> True, you might call all these "exceptions". True, they deter from the
pure model. Still, they are
> common, and are easily resolved by placing tests in the same package.
On the other hand, I don't see the
> actual harm of doing so.

But, not so common as they need to be. There will always be exceptions,
most likely, but they shouldn't become the norm simply because they make
things a little easier. The old addage is, "No pain, no gain." If you
simply take the easy way out you design will absolutely suffer! Again, I
believe tests are a way to strengthen the design, not weaken it.

> B.t.w., the right access mode for "accessible in package only" is
"default". "protected" makes it
> accessible to both package members and subclassses.

Thanks. I know that, but it's good to be corrected, especially when your
mistakes are in writing.

BTW: Just in case anyone is feeling slighted by my seemingly dogmatic
approach -- it is not my intention to pick on anyone's person, but I don't
mind pointing out what I think are flaws in the process :) After all, what
is this group for if we pander to people just so we don't hurt feelings and
never get to the bottoms of the issues. ...just a friendly disclaimer from
your test-infected fellow.

-Jason
